Parents and students are reminded to log in to Final Forms by August 7 to select your educational platform for the first semester of the 2020-21 school year:

Option 1 is the SCHOOL-BASED TRACK, which is in-person instruction as local health risk levels permit. Western Reserve Local School District will continue to follow guidance from local health department, ODE, and OHSAA to ensure student, staff, and community safety. Learning levels (in-person, remote, or combination) will correspond to the Huron County Risk Level.

Option 2 is ONLINE LEARNING through North Point ESC's PLP, or PERSONAL LEARNING PLAN. This is a fully online option for students who are seeking an alternative to in-person instruction. Students will remain Western Reserve Roughriders. Grades Pre-K to 12 are available and require a semester-long commitment. Students will be issued necessary equipment.

Two posts will follow that will show you the content of what you can expect from the online forum should you select North Point's online learning forum. Please watch one or both videos for more information.

According to Google, one definition of wag (with reference to an animal's tail) is, "to move or cause to move rapidly to and fro." At Western Reserve MS/HS we have created an additional definition of the word wag: "to spread joy and happiness!"

Anyone who has ever come into contact with our therapy dog, Birdie, knows that she does both every day! Mrs. French, Mrs. Todd, and members of the senior class are kicking off a kindness campaign for the month of March that encourages the 'wag'! As part of that campaign and as a fundraiser for the senior class trip, Birdie merchandise is being sold and you can purchase it through the link provided.

Stay tuned for more information on our kindness campaign where we will be asking students the question "how do you wag?" in an effort to move and spread joy and happiness throughout our school community.

https://www.spencerscustomapparel.com/western_reserve_birdie_merchand/shop/home

Their effort was outstanding and their resilience was extraordinary.

Congrats to these four students on a job well done and for representing Western Reserve at this academic event!
